# Search Result
From [Source](https://english.factcrescendo.com/international/viral-image-showing-explosion-of-iphone-is-unrelated-to-the-blasts-in-lebanon-619150/): Found exact image on website with title: Viral image showing explosion of iPhone is unrelated to the blasts in ...
Content: "

! <image:11531>

An image showing an exploded iPhone is going viral on social media with the claim that an iPhone has exploded in Lebanon along with the recent blast of other electronic devices. The caption states, “iPhones exploding in #Lebanon blowing up random people”.

Let’s check the truth

! <image:11532>

> iPhones exploding in [#Lebanon](https://twitter.com/hashtag/Lebanon?src=hash&ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw)
>  blowing up random people. 🚨🚨🚨 [pic.twitter.com/muqAiBS9T5](https://t.co/muqAiBS9T5)
> 
> — SilencedSirs◼️ (@SilentlySirs) [September 18, 2024](https://twitter.com/SilentlySirs/status/1836456815326040253?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw)

[https://archive.org/details/c-image\_202409](https://archive.org/details/c-image_202409)

**Fact Check-** 

We started our investigation with a reverse image search on Google and the results led us to a report by the Egyptian outlet Cairo 24 published on 19 March 2021.According to the report, the image shows an iPhone explosion that caused severe injuries, including a broken arm to a kid. The incident had taken place in Maadi, Egypt.

! <image:11533>

[Archive link](https://archive.org/details/untitled_20240923_1305)

The report further states that a child named Hamza from Al Maadi, Egypt, suffered a broken arm while attempting to escape a fire that broke out after an iPhone exploded while it was charging. Following the incident, the father filed a police report, accusing the iPhone company of negligence, stating that the phone was less than a month old.

Moving forward, we found an article in an Arabic website named [nabd.com](https://nabd.com/s/85455852-535a14/)
 published on 20 March 2021 with the same details. It states a child was injured due to iPhone explosion in Maadi, Cairo.

! <image:11534>
========================================================================================================================================================================================================================================================================

[Archive link](https://web.archive.org/web/20240923134834/https:/nabd.com/s/85455852-535a14/)

**Conclusion**

Fact Crescendo found the claim made along with the viral image to be Misleading. This image of an exploded iPhone is from the 2021 incident in a suburb of Cairo, Egypt. Not from Lebanon.

![Avatar](https://srilanka.factcrescendo.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/Misleading.png
)

**Fact Check By: [Usha Manoj](/cdn-cgi/l/email-protection#bbd2d5ddd4fbdddad8cfd8c9dec8d8ded5dfd495d8d4d6)** 

**Result:** Misleading


# Search Result
From [Source](https://lieber.westpoint.edu/well-it-depends-explosive-pagers-attack-revisited/): 
Content: "[](https://www.addtoany.com/add_to/facebook?linkurl=https%3A%2F%2Flieber.westpoint.edu%2Fwell-it-depends-explosive-pagers-attack-revisited%2F&linkname=%E2%80%9CWell%2C%20it%20Depends%E2%80%9D%3A%20The%20Explosive%20Pagers%20Attack%20Revisited "Facebook")
[](https://www.addtoany.com/add_to/twitter?linkurl=https%3A%2F%2Flieber.westpoint.edu%2Fwell-it-depends-explosive-pagers-attack-revisited%2F&linkname=%E2%80%9CWell%2C%20it%20Depends%E2%80%9D%3A%20The%20Explosive%20Pagers%20Attack%20Revisited "Twitter")
[](https://www.addtoany.com/add_to/email?linkurl=https%3A%2F%2Flieber.westpoint.edu%2Fwell-it-depends-explosive-pagers-attack-revisited%2F&linkname=%E2%80%9CWell%2C%20it%20Depends%E2%80%9D%3A%20The%20Explosive%20Pagers%20Attack%20Revisited "Email")
[](https://www.addtoany.com/add_to/linkedin?linkurl=https%3A%2F%2Flieber.westpoint.edu%2Fwell-it-depends-explosive-pagers-attack-revisited%2F&linkname=%E2%80%9CWell%2C%20it%20Depends%E2%80%9D%3A%20The%20Explosive%20Pagers%20Attack%20Revisited "LinkedIn")
[](https://www.addtoany.com/add_to/print?linkurl=https%3A%2F%2Flieber.westpoint.edu%2Fwell-it-depends-explosive-pagers-attack-revisited%2F&linkname=%E2%80%9CWell%2C%20it%20Depends%E2%80%9D%3A%20The%20Explosive%20Pagers%20Attack%20Revisited "Print")

“Well, it Depends”: The Explosive Pagers Attack Revisited
=========================================================

by [Amichai Cohen](https://lieber.westpoint.edu/author/amichai-cohen/ "Amichai Cohen")
, [Yuval Shany](https://lieber.westpoint.edu/author/yuvalshany/ "Yuval Shany") | Oct 11, 2024

![](https://lieber.westpoint.edu/wp-content/uploads/2024/10/Yamaha_MODX6.webp "Yamaha_MODX6")

On 17 September, 2024, thousands of pagers distributed by Hezbollah to its operatives in Lebanon and Syria exploded. While no State acknowledged responsibility for these explosions, [media reports](https://edition.cnn.com/2024/09/27/middleeast/israel-pager-attack-hezbollah-lebanon-invs-intl/index.html)
 have strongly suggested that Israel is responsible for them.

[_New York Times_](https://www.nytimes.com/2024/09/18/world/middleeast/israel-exploding-pagers-hezbollah.html)
 and [_Washington Post_](https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/2024/10/05/israel-mossad-hezbollah-pagers-nasrallah/)
 reporting suggests the following sequence of events. We note in this regard that between 8 October 2023 and 17 September 2024, [Hezbollah fired](https://thehill.com/policy/defense/4893654-hezbollah-has-fired-more-than-8000-rockets-toward-israel-since-october-7-ambassador/)
 more than 8,000 rockets towards Israel, [reaching a peak](https://www.inss.org.il/publication/war-data/)
 of 1,300 rockets in the month of August alone. The fact that the Israeli major counter-attack was undertaken almost a year after Hezbollah’s attacks started, following a series of failed attempts to end Hezbollah’s use of force through resorting to more [measured military responses](https://www.reuters.com/world/middle-east/israel-strikes-hezbollah-targets-lebanon-military-says-2024-08-25/)
 and [diplomatic means](https://www.arabnews.com/node/2475451)
, appears to us to clearly meet the _jus ad bellum_ test of necessity.

In the same vein, the [argument](https://x.com/BCFinucane/status/1840416147360854526)
 that Israel was legally required to accept a ceasefire deal in Gaza—on terms which it considers [unacceptable](https://news.sky.com/story/israels-benjamin-netanyahu-rejects-ceasefire-deal-that-would-leave-hamas-intact-13129727)
 to it (i.e., which would leave Hamas in control of the Gaza Strip)—in order to stop Hezbollah’s rocket attacks, and that its failure to do so implies lack of military necessity, appears to us to be baseless. It has also been reported that the explosive charges installed in the pagers were relatively [small](https://edition.cnn.com/2024/09/27/middleeast/israel-pager-attack-hezbollah-lebanon-invs-intl/index.html)
, leading mostly to injuries and not deaths. As early as 2020, Hezbollah’s late leader, Hassan Nasrallah, warned members of the group against the use of cell phones, because he feared Israel was monitoring their cell phone conversations, and tracking their movements. In February 2024, Hezbollah decided to go “low tech” in order to evade Israel’s monitoring.

Anticipating this, Israel formed a shell corporation in Hungary called B.A.C. The actual explosion occurred shortly afterwards either by pager holders pressing two buttons manually with both of their hands to view the encrypted message or through a second activating message.

On 17 September, the detonation order was given and thousands of pagers exploded. Twelve persons were reportedly killed by the explosions (two of them children, most likely of Hezbollah operatives). On 18 September, a second set of explosions took place resulting in more casualties."

# Your Summary



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The search result from Lieber Institute of Law & Warfare discusses the explosive pager attacks on Hezbollah operatives in Lebanon and Syria on September 17, 2024. The article mentions that Israel is strongly suggested to be responsible for the explosions. The explosions resulted in injuries and deaths, with twelve people reportedly killed. The article was published on October 11, 2024.

# Instructions
In order to find evidence that helps your fact-check, you just ran a web search which yielded a Search Result. **Your task right now is to summarize the Search Result.** What to include:
* information that might be useful for the fact-check (see Record)
* relevant images (refer to images by inserting their reference <image:k>)
* if available: the release date as well as the author or the publisher (e.g. the media company) of the search result.

Do NOT include:
* advertisements
* any other information not related to the Record or the Claim

Additional rules:
* Do not add any additional information besides the information in the Search Result.
* If the Search Result doesn't contain any relevant information for the fact-checking work, simply print one word in capital letters: "NONE".
* Keep your writing style like in the Examples 1, 2 and 3 provided to you.
* Try to filter out relevant information even if the search result is in a different language.

The Guardian mentions the Chemical Weapons Convention and the responsibilities of Syria under the convention. According to The Guardian, The White House condemned the Assad regime for defying the norm against chemical weapons use.

## Claim
Claim: "<image:10226> This image shows an Iphone that exploded during the pager attacks on Hezbollah devices in Lebanon in September 2024, blowing up random people."

# Search Result
From [Source](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2024_Lebanon_electronic_device_attacks): 
Content: "The incident was described as Hezbollah's biggest security breach since the start of the [Israel–Hezbollah conflict](/wiki/Israel%E2%80%93Hezbollah_conflict_(2023%E2%80%93present) "Israel–Hezbollah conflict (2023–present)")
 in October 2023.[\[15\]](#cite_note-BBC-17)

The first wave of explosions on 17 September targeted pagers,[\[16\]](#cite_note-:3-18)
 killing at least 12 people, including two Hezbollah members and two children,[\[15\]](#cite_note-BBC-17)
[\[17\]](#cite_note-19)
[\[18\]](#cite_note-20)
 and wounding more than 2,750,[\[19\]](#cite_note-Associated_Press-21)
 including [Iran](/wiki/Iran "Iran")
's ambassador to Lebanon.[\[20\]](#cite_note-22)
 The second wave on 18 September targeted [Icom](/wiki/Icom_Incorporated "Icom Incorporated")
 walkie-talkies, killing at least 30 people and injuring over 750.[\[7\]](#cite_note-auto-8)
[\[21\]](#cite_note-23)
[\[16\]](#cite_note-:3-18)
 The 150 hospitals across Lebanon that received victims of the explosions experienced chaotic scenes.[\[22\]](#cite_note-Al_Jazeera-3-24)
[\[23\]](#cite_note-France24-25)
 UN human rights experts condemned the attacks as potential war crimes, stating that while some victims may not have been civilians, the indiscriminate nature of the simultaneous explosions violated international law and the right to life.[\[16\]](#cite_note-:3-18)
 Some Hezbollah members who carried the pagers were not part of the organization's military wing.

Seven months before the explosions, Hezbollah's secretary-general [Hassan Nasrallah](/wiki/Hassan_Nasrallah "Hassan Nasrallah")
 instructed the group's members to use pagers instead of cell phones, claiming Israel had infiltrated their cell phone network.[\[24\]](#cite_note-The_New_York_Times-3-26)
[\[25\]](#cite_note-Al_Jazeera-2-27)
 About five months before the explosions,[\[26\]](#cite_note-28)
 Hezbollah purchased Gold Apollo AR-924 pagers.[\[27\]](#cite_note-CNN-2-29)
[\[28\]](#cite_note-The_Times_of_Israel-30)
[\[29\]](#cite_note-Wired-31)
 The Israeli intelligence agency [Mossad](/wiki/Mossad "Mossad")
 had secretly manufactured and integrated the explosive [PETN](/wiki/PETN "PETN")
 into the devices, and sold them to Hezbollah through a [shell company](/wiki/Shell_company "Shell company")
.[\[30\]](#cite_note-nyt-fbs-trojan-24-32)
[\[31\]](#cite_note-33)
 Responding to the attacks, Nasrallah described the explosions as a "major blow"[\[32\]](#cite_note-:5-34)
 and labeled them an [act of war](/wiki/Casus_belli "Casus belli")
,[\[33\]](#cite_note-35)
 possibly a [declaration of war](/wiki/Declaration_of_war "Declaration of war")
 by Israel.[\[34\]](#cite_note-36)
[\[c\]](#cite_note-37)
 Initially Israel neither denied nor confirmed a role,[\[35\]](#cite_note-38)
 but in November 2024 Israeli prime minister [Benjamin Netanyahu](/wiki/Benjamin_Netanyahu "Benjamin Netanyahu")
 confirmed Israeli responsibility.[\[36\]](#cite_note-:2-39)
 Following the explosions, Israeli Defence Minister [Yoav Gallant](/wiki/Yoav_Gallant "Yoav Gallant")
 announced a "new phase" of the war in northern Israel and Lebanon had begun.[\[37\]](#cite_note-40)
 Hezbollah vowed retaliation,[\[38\]](#cite_note-Reuters-2-41)
 launching a rocket attack on northern Israel a few days later that struck cities such as [Nazareth](/wiki/Nazareth "Nazareth")
 and [Kiryat Bialik](/wiki/Kiryat_Bialik "Kiryat Bialik")
, injuring several civilians.[\[39\]](#cite_note-:6-42)
 Ten days after the device explosions, Israel killed Nasrallah [in an airstrike](/wiki/2024_Hezbollah_headquarters_strike "2024 Hezbollah headquarters strike")
 in Beirut.[\[40\]](#cite_note-43)
 On 27 November, [a ceasefire agreement between Israel and Lebanon](/wiki/2024_Israel%E2%80%93Lebanon_ceasefire_agreement "2024 Israel–Lebanon ceasefire agreement")
 went into effect, although some attacks continue.[\[41\]](#cite_note-44)
[\[42\]](#cite_note-45)
 The attack was planned over a ten-year span.[\[43\]](#cite_note-46)
 Some commentators described the operation as "sophisticated"[\[44\]](#cite_note-47)
 and an "extraordinary feat of [espionage](/wiki/Espionage "Espionage")
,"[\[45\]](#cite_note-48)
 while others called it the "most precise [anti-terrorist](/wiki/Counterterrorism "Counterterrorism")
 attack" ever conducted.[\[46\]](#cite_note-49)

Background
----------

Main article: [Israel–Hezbollah conflict (2023–present)](/wiki/Israel%E2%80%93Hezbollah_conflict_(2023%E2%80%93present) "Israel–Hezbollah conflict (2023–present)")

Hezbollah was founded in 1982 by Lebanese clerics in response to the [Israeli invasion of Lebanon](/wiki/1982_Lebanon_War "1982 Lebanon War")
.[\[47\]](#cite_note-bbc-hi-me2-50)
[\[48\]](#cite_note-51)
[\[49\]](#cite_note-52)
 Shortly after the onset of the [Gaza war](/wiki/Gaza_war "Gaza war")
 in October 2023, Hezbollah joined the conflict, citing solidarity with Palestinians.[\[50\]](#cite_note-aj-53)
 This quickly escalated into regular cross-border military exchanges between Hezbollah and Israel, impacting [northern Israel](/wiki/Northern_Israel "Northern Israel")
, [southern Lebanon](/wiki/Southern_Lebanon "Southern Lebanon")
 and the [Golan Heights](/wiki/Golan_Heights "Golan Heights")
.[\[51\]](#cite_note-54)
 Hezbollah said it aimed to pressure Israel by forcing it to fight on two fronts.[\[52\]](#cite_note-55)
 Hezbollah has offered an immediate ceasefire should [a ceasefire also happen in Gaza](/wiki/Calls_for_a_ceasefire_during_the_Gaza_war "Calls for a ceasefire during the Gaza war")
,[\[53\]](#cite_note-56)
[\[54\]](#cite_note-57)
 where over [50,000 Palestinians have been killed](/wiki/Casualties_of_the_Gaza_war "Casualties of the Gaza war")
, with at least half identified as women and children.[\[55\]](#cite_note-58)
 From 8 October 2023 to 20 September 2024, Hezbollah has launched 1,900 cross border attacks, and Israel has launched another 8,300.[\[56\]](#cite_note-59)
 The fighting killed 564 in Lebanon (including 133 civilians)[\[57\]](#cite_note-leb-displace-60)
 and 52 in Israel (including 27 civilians), displacing entire communities in both countries,[\[57\]](#cite_note-leb-displace-60)
 with significant damage to civilian infrastructure.[\[58\]](#cite_note-61)

On 10 September, the Israeli Defense Minister [Yoav Gallant](/wiki/Yoav_Gallant "Yoav Gallant")
 said Israel was shifting its focus from Gaza to the northern border.[\[59\]](#cite_note-62)
 Israel's domestic security agency, [Shin Bet](/wiki/Shin_Bet "Shin Bet")
, announced it had thwarted a Hezbollah plot to assassinate a former senior defense official using an explosive device, and _[The Jerusalem Post](/wiki/The_Jerusalem_Post "The Jerusalem Post")
_ speculated that the pager explosions may have been in retaliation.[\[60\]](#cite_note-63)
[\[61\]](#cite_note-64)

### Use of pagers

While popular in the late twentieth century, pagers have since largely been replaced by cell phones, except in hospitals.[\[62\]](#cite_note-65)
 Some Hezbollah members had used pagers for years before the [7 October attacks](/wiki/2023_Hamas-led_attack_on_Israel "2023 Hamas-led attack on Israel")
, but more members began using them after February 2024, when Hezbollah secretary-general [Hassan Nasrallah](/wiki/Hassan_Nasrallah "Hassan Nasrallah")
 called on members to stop using smartphones, citing Israel's capability to infiltrate them.[\[24\]](#cite_note-The_New_York_Times-3-26)
[\[25\]](#cite_note-Al_Jazeera-2-27)
 Hezbollah subsequently imported the pagers to Lebanon in the months before the explosion.[\[28\]](#cite_note-The_Times_of_Israel-30)
[\[27\]](#cite_note-CNN-2-29)
 Reuters was told that the explosives were not detected despite checks and the pagers were still being distributed immediately before the attack.[\[63\]](#cite_note-66)

Israeli agencies have previously carried out operations involving explosive communication devices—notably the assassination of Hamas operative [Yahya Ayyash](/wiki/Yahya_Ayyash "Yahya Ayyash")
 in 1996.[\[64\]](#cite_note-The_Economist-67)

In 2015, Mossad began planting booby-trapped walkie-talkies in Lebanon, which secretly allowed Israel to monitor Hezbollah communications while holding the option to detonate them.[\[65\]](#cite_note-:14-68)
 For nine years, Israel limited its use of these devices to surveillance. [Jump to content](#bodyContent)

"Assassination of Hashem Safieddine")<br>    <br>*   [Israeli attacks on the Lebanese health sector](/wiki/Israeli_attacks_on_the_Lebanese_health_sector_during_the_Israel-Hezbollah_conflict_(2023%E2%80%93present) "Israeli attacks on the Lebanese health sector during the Israel-Hezbollah conflict (2023–present)")<br>    <br><br>Iran, Iraq and Syria<br><br>*   [Attacks on US bases](/wiki/Attacks_on_US_bases_during_the_Gaza_war "Attacks on US bases during the Gaza war")<br>    *   [Tower 22 drone attack](/wiki/Tower_22_drone_attack "Tower 22 drone attack")<br>        <br>*   [February 2024 US airstrikes](/wiki/February_2024_United_States_airstrikes_in_Iraq_and_Syria "February 2024 United States airstrikes in Iraq and Syria")<br>    <br>*   [Assassination of Razi Mousavi](/wiki/Razi_Mousavi "Razi Mousavi")<br>    <br>*   [2024 Erbil attack](/wiki/2024_Erbil_attack "2024 Erbil attack")<br>    <br>*   [Assassination of Sadegh Omidzadeh](/wiki/Assassination_of_Sadegh_Omidzadeh "Assassination of Sadegh Omidzadeh")<br>    <br>*   [2024 Homs airstrikes](/wiki/2024_Homs_airstrikes "2024 Homs airstrikes")<br>    <br>*   [Iranian consulate in Damascus airstrike](/wiki/Israeli_airstrike_on_the_Iranian_consulate_in_Damascus "Israeli airstrike on the Iranian consulate in Damascus")<br>    <br>*   [2024 Iran–Israel conflict](/wiki/2024_Iran%E2%80%93Israel_conflict "2024 Iran–Israel conflict")<br>    *   [April 2024 Iranian strikes](/wiki/April_2024_Iranian_strikes_on_Israel "April 2024 Iranian strikes on Israel")<br>        <br>    *   [April 2024 Israeli strikes](/wiki/April_2024_Israeli_strikes_on_Iran "April 2024 Israeli strikes on Iran")<br>        <br>    *   [October 2024 Iranian strikes](/wiki/October_2024_Iranian_strikes_on_Israel "October 2024 Iranian strikes on Israel")<br>        <br>    *   [October 2024 Israeli strikes](/wiki/October_2024_Israeli_strikes_on_Iran "October 2024 Israeli strikes on Iran")<br>        <br>*   [Assassination of Ismail Haniyeh](/wiki/Assassination_of_Ismail_Haniyeh "Assassination of Ismail Haniyeh")<br>    <br>*   [Masyaf strikes](/wiki/2024_Masyaf_strikes "2024 Masyaf strikes")<br>    <br>*   [2024 leak of U.S. Experts found explosive and flammable liquids inside the devices.[\[84\]](#cite_note-87)

Explosions
----------

### Day 1: exploding pagers

Security camera footage showing exploding pager in Beirut

On 17 September 2024 at around 15:30 EEST,[\[19\]](#cite_note-Associated_Press-21)
 many pagers across Lebanon and Syria unexpectedly exploded in an apparently coordinated attack on Hezbollah members, many of whom were seriously wounded.[\[85\]](#cite_note-The_New_York_Times-2-88)
[\[38\]](#cite_note-Reuters-2-41)
[\[15\]](#cite_note-BBC-17)
 According to the [Lebanese Health Ministry](/wiki/Ministry_of_Public_Health_(Lebanon) "Ministry of Public Health (Lebanon)")
, the vast majority of those who came to emergency rooms were in civilian clothing and their Hezbollah affiliation was unclear.[\[86\]](#cite_note-guardian_abiad-89)

Facial and eye injuries were the most common effect of the explosions and, according to [Tracy Chamoun](/wiki/Tracy_Chamoun "Tracy Chamoun")
, the pagers emitted a sound to encourage users to pick the devices up and lift them to their heads.[\[87\]](#cite_note-90)
 Other reports say that the device vibrated and showed an error message on the screen, and only detonated when the user pressed a button to clear the error, increasing the chance that the operator of the device would be holding it.[\[19\]](#cite_note-Associated_Press-21)
 Iranian ambassador to Lebanon [Mojtaba Amani](/wiki/Mojtaba_Amani "Mojtaba Amani")
, along with two additional embassy staffers, were injured in the attack.[\[3\]](#cite_note-CNN-3-3)
 Amani testified that a “special beep” sounded followed by the text, “You have an important message.” The detonation occurred on pushing a button to read it.[\[88\]](#cite_note-91)
 Amani lost one eye and suffered severe injuries in the other.[\[89\]](#cite_note-92)
[\[90\]](#cite_note-93)
 According to reports, the message that appeared on the pager was encrypted and required two buttons be simultaneously pressed, which in practice meant both hands had to be used to read the message.[\[91\]](#cite_note-Edelson-2024-10-06-94)

Explosions occurred in several areas where Hezbollah has a strong presence,[\[19\]](#cite_note-Associated_Press-21)
 including its stronghold of [Dahieh](/wiki/Dahieh "Dahieh")
 in [Beirut](/wiki/Beirut "Beirut")
; [southern Lebanon](/wiki/Southern_Lebanon "Southern Lebanon")
; and the [Beqaa Valley](/wiki/Beqaa_Valley "Beqaa Valley")
 near the Syrian border,[\[38\]](#cite_note-Reuters-2-41)
[\[15\]](#cite_note-BBC-17)
[\[3\]](#cite_note-CNN-3-3)
 where explosions were reported in the towns of [Aali en Nahri](/wiki/Aali_en_Nahri "Aali en Nahri")
 and [Riyaq](/wiki/Riyaq "Riyaq")
.[\[3\]](#cite_note-CNN-3-3)
 In Syria, explosions of pagers were also reported in [Damascus](/wiki/Damascus "Damascus")
 and its vicinity.[\[92\]](#cite_note-95)
[\[93\]](#cite_note-96)
 Blasts reportedly continued for up to 30 minutes after the initial detonations, intensifying the resulting chaos.[\[94\]](#cite_note-The_Jerusalem_Post-2-97)

Witnesses reported seeing multiple individuals with bleeding wounds in the aftermath of the blasts.[\[38\]](#cite_note-Reuters-2-41)
 In one instance, an explosion occurred inside the trouser pockets of a man standing outside a shop.[\[95\]](#cite_note-98)
 Photos and videos circulating on social media and local media from Beirut's southern suburbs showed individuals lying on the ground with injuries on their hands or near their pockets.[\[96\]](#cite_note-99)

Around 150 hospitals received victims of the attack, which saw chaotic scenes.[\[23\]](#cite_note-France24-25)
[\[22\]](#cite_note-Al_Jazeera-3-24)
 Hospitals in southern Lebanon, the Beqaa Valley, and Beirut's southern suburbs were overwhelmed with patients, many suffering from injuries to the face, hands and waist.[\[97\]](#cite_note-BBC-2-100)
[\[98\]](#cite_note-101)
 In response, the Ministry of Health advised individuals with pagers to dispose of them and instructed hospitals to remain on "high alert".[\[3\]](#cite_note-CNN-3-3)
 It also called on health workers to report to work and asked them not to use wireless devices.[\[19\]](#cite_note-Associated_Press-21)
[\[27\]](#cite_note-CNN-2-29)
 The state-run [National News Agency](/wiki/National_News_Agency_(Lebanon) "National News Agency (Lebanon)")
 appealed for blood donations.[\[99\]](#cite_note-102)
 Ambulance crews were deployed from the northern cities of [Tripoli](/wiki/Tripoli,_Lebanon "Tripoli, Lebanon")
 and [Al-Qalamoun](/wiki/Al-Qalamoun "Al-Qalamoun")
 to help in Beirut.[\[27\]](#cite_note-CNN-2-29)

The attack came just a day after the [Biden administration](/wiki/Biden_administration "Biden administration")
's special envoy [Amos Hochstein](/wiki/Amos_Hochstein "Amos Hochstein")
 visited Israel and warned Prime Minister [Benjamin Netanyahu](/wiki/Benjamin_Netanyahu "Benjamin Netanyahu")
 against provoking a major escalation in Lebanon.[\[100\]](#cite_note-Axios-103)
 Just before the blasts, Israeli defence minister [Yoav Gallant](/wiki/Yoav_Gallant "Yoav Gallant")
 told the US defense secretary [Lloyd Austin](/wiki/Lloyd_Austin "Lloyd Austin")
 that an operation was planned in Lebanon.[\[101\]](#cite_note-104)

### Day 2: exploding walkie-talkies

At around 17:00 EEST on 18 September, about 24 hours after the initial attack, a second wave of explosions occurred, targeting handheld radios.[\[102\]](#cite_note-BBC-ce9jglrnmkvo-105)
[\[103\]](#cite_note-106)

Explosions were reported in Beirut, the Bekaa Valley, and southern Lebanon.[\[104\]](#cite_note-107)
 The explosions also caused fires in at least two homes.[\[105\]](#cite_note-108)
 Other explosions occurred at a funeral held in Beirut for three Hezbollah members and a child who had been killed by the initial explosions.[\[106\]](#cite_note-109)
 [Lebanese Civil Defense](/wiki/Lebanese_Civil_Defense "Lebanese Civil Defense")
 said it responded to fires in at least 71 homes and shops,[\[107\]](#cite_note-:9-110)
 including a lithium battery store in [Majdel Selm](/wiki/Majdel_Selm "Majdel Selm")
, as well as 15 cars and numerous motorcycles. These fires were triggered by explosions in various locations across [Nabatieh Governorate](/wiki/Nabatieh_Governorate "Nabatieh Governorate")
.[\[108\]](#cite_note-lorientlejour-111)

One compromised device was discovered inside an ambulance outside the [American University of Beirut Medical Center](/wiki/American_University_of_Beirut#AUB_Medical_Center "American University of Beirut")
 (AUBMC) and neutralized in a [controlled explosion](/wiki/Controlled_explosion "Controlled explosion")
 by the [Lebanese Army](/wiki/Lebanese_Army "Lebanese Army")
.[\[109\]](#cite_note-112)
 Hezbollah supporters reportedly prevented journalists from filming the incident at the AUBMC.[\[108\]](#cite_note-lorientlejour-111)
[\[110\]](#cite_note-113)
 The [Lebanese Red Cross](/wiki/Lebanese_Red_Cross "Lebanese Red Cross")
 dispatched 30 ambulances to transport victims in the affected areas.[\[102\]](#cite_note-BBC-ce9jglrnmkvo-105)

The targeted devices were reported as [Icom](/wiki/Icom_Incorporated "Icom Incorporated")
 [IC-V82](/wiki/Icom_IC-V82 "Icom IC-V82")
 [VHF](/wiki/2-meter_band "2-meter band")
 [walkie-talkies](/wiki/Walkie-talkie "Walkie-talkie")
, known to be used by Hezbollah.[\[107\]](#cite_note-:9-110)
 Manufacture of the IC-V82 model ceased in 2014,[\[111\]](#cite_note-114)
 and Icom had previously issued an advisory warning about counterfeit radios, including the IC-V82.[\[112\]](#cite_note-115)
 The company said on 19 September that it was conducting an investigation[\[113\]](#cite_note-116)
 and, two days later, announced that it was "highly unlikely" that the radios were theirs.[\[114\]](#cite_note-117)
 A sales executive at Icom's US subsidiary said the transceivers involved appeared to be "knockoff" (counterfeit) products.[\[115\]](#cite_note-118)

Other electronic devices, such as [fingerprint biometric devices](/wiki/Biometric_device "Biometric device")
, were also reported to have exploded, though it remains unclear whether those devices caught fire from other explosions or detonated on their own.[\[116\]](#cite_note-week2-119)
[\[117\]](#cite_note-Marsi-120)
[\[118\]](#cite_note-The_Guardian-121)

In the aftermath of the second wave of explosions, a group of men attacked [United Nations Interim Force in Lebanon](/wiki/United_Nations_Interim_Force_in_Lebanon "United Nations Interim Force in Lebanon")
 vehicles in [Tyre](/wiki/Tyre,_Lebanon "Tyre, Lebanon")
, before Lebanese armed forces intervened.[\[119\]](#cite_note-122)
[\[120\]](#cite_note-123)

Deaths and injuries
-------------------

### Deaths

As of 22 September 2024[\[update\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=2024_Lebanon_electronic_device_attacks&action=edit)
, the death toll from the attacks was 42.[\[11\]](#cite_note-:10-13)
 At least 12 people were killed in the first wave of attacks (17 September),[\[1\]](#cite_note-Associated_Press-2-1)
 including a 9-year-old girl and an 11-year-old boy.[\[121\]](#cite_note-124)
[\[122\]](#cite_note-125)
[\[123\]](#cite_note-126)
 In the second wave on 18 September, at least 30 people were killed and 750 others were injured.[\[7\]](#cite_note-auto-8)
[\[19\]](#cite_note-Associated_Press-21)
 The adult son of [Ali Ammar](/wiki/Ali_Ammar_(politician) "Ali Ammar (politician)")
, a Hezbollah [member of Parliament](/wiki/Parliament_of_Lebanon "Parliament of Lebanon")
 was killed;[\[124\]](#cite_note-:11-127)
 Lebanon's Prime Minister [Najib Mikati](/wiki/Najib_Mikati "Najib Mikati")
 visited southern Beirut to pay his respects.[\[24\]](#cite_note-The_New_York_Times-3-26)

### Injuries

On 20 September 2024, it was reported that more than 3,500 people were injured.[\[11\]](#cite_note-:10-13)

On 17 September Health Minister [Firass Abiad](/wiki/Firass_Abiad "Firass Abiad")
 said the vast majority of those being treated in emergency rooms were in civilian clothing and their Hezbollah affiliation was unclear,[\[125\]](#cite_note-128)
 but casualties included elderly people as well as young children. As of 18 September, it was unclear if only Hezbollah members were carrying the pagers.[\[126\]](#cite_note-ABC_News-129)
 During his speech on 19 September, Secretary-General Nasrallah clarified the exploded pagers were those distributed to lower ranking members while Hezbollah's leaders did not use the model.[\[127\]](#cite_note-:4-130)
 According to the Health Ministry, healthcare workers were also injured and it advised all healthcare workers to discard their pagers.[\[128\]](#cite_note-BBC-3-131)
[\[129\]](#cite_note-132)
 On 26 September, [Abdallah Bou Habib](/wiki/Abdallah_Bou_Habib "Abdallah Bou Habib")
, Lebanon's Foreign Minister, confirmed that most of those carrying pagers were not fighters, but civilians like administrators.[\[130\]](#cite_note-habib-133)
 Qassim Qassir, a Lebanese expert on Hezbollah,[\[d\]](#cite_note-fn1-134)
 said the attacks mostly struck civilian workers, leaving its military wing largely unaffected.[\[131\]](#cite_note-:13-135)
 On 11 November, [Mustafa Bairam](/w/index.php?title=Mustafa_Bairam&action=edit&redlink=1 "Mustafa Bairam (page does not exist)")
 \[[ar](https://ar.wikipedia.org/wiki/%D9%85%D8%B5%D8%B7%D9%81%D9%89_%D8%A8%D9%8A%D8%B1%D9%85 "ar:مصطفى بيرم")\
; [de](https://de.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mustafa_Bayram "de:Mustafa Bayram")\
\], the Lebanese [Labour Minister](/wiki/Council_of_Ministers_of_Lebanon "Council of Ministers of Lebanon")
, made a formal complaint to the United Nations’ [International Labour Organization](/wiki/International_Labour_Organization "International Labour Organization")
 (ILO), in which he stated that the pagers wounded or killed 4,000 civilians – much higher than initial reports of casualties.[\[13\]](#cite_note-:0-15)

One eye doctor at Mount Lebanon University Hospital reported that a number of those injured showed signs of something being blown up directly in their face, with some losing one or both eyes, while others had shrapnel in their brains.[\[132\]](#cite_note-136)
[\[133\]](#cite_note-137)
 The Lebanese health ministry reported that 300 people had lost both eyes and 500 people had lost one eye as a result of the pager attacks.[\[134\]](#cite_note-FR24_1-138)
 Other doctors saw severe hand, waist and facial injuries, reporting patients with fingers torn, hands amputated, eyes popped out of the socket and facial lacerations.[\[135\]](#cite_note-139)
 An unnamed Hezbollah official told [Reuters](/wiki/Reuters "Reuters")
 1,500 Hezbollah fighters were taken out of action by injuries.[\[10\]](#cite_note-:17-12)
 The Iranian Ministry of Health reported that it treated 500 victims by performing more than 1,500 eye and limb surgeries, and that Iran sent 12 doctors to Lebanon to assist in treatment.[\[136\]](#cite_note-140)
[\[137\]](#cite_note-141)
\[_[better source needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:NOTRS "Wikipedia:NOTRS")\
_\]

Impact
------

Further information: [September 2024 Lebanon strikes](/wiki/September_2024_Lebanon_strikes "September 2024 Lebanon strikes")

### Lebanon

Lebanese health minister [Firas Abiad](/wiki/Firas_Abiad "Firas Abiad")
 said the scale of the attack was greater than the [2020 Beirut explosion](/wiki/2020_Beirut_explosion "2020 Beirut explosion")
, which was one of the [largest artificial non-nuclear explosions](/wiki/Largest_artificial_non-nuclear_explosions "Largest artificial non-nuclear explosions")
 ever recorded.[\[138\]](#cite_note-142)
[\[139\]](#cite_note-143)
 The head of Lebanon's disaster response committee also compared the pager attack with the Beirut explosion, in terms of the sudden influx of casualties and the strain imposed on Lebanon's [emergency response](/wiki/Emergency_response "Emergency response")
 system.[\[140\]](#cite_note-144)
 Many Lebanese doctors who were treating the injured concurred that the level of injuries was greater than that after the port explosion.[\[141\]](#cite_note-145)

Schools were closed in Lebanon on 18 September,[\[27\]](#cite_note-CNN-2-29)
 and the [Lebanese army](/wiki/Lebanese_army "Lebanese army")
 announced it was conducting [controlled blasts](/wiki/Bomb_disposal "Bomb disposal")
 in various areas to destroy any suspicious devices.[\[142\]](#cite_note-146)

On 19 September, the [Lebanese Civil Aviation Authority](/wiki/Lebanese_Civil_Aviation_Authority "Lebanese Civil Aviation Authority")
 imposed an indefinite ban on carrying pagers and walkie-talkies inside checked luggage and carry-on items on flights at [Beirut–Rafic Hariri International Airport](/wiki/Beirut%E2%80%93Rafic_Hariri_International_Airport "Beirut–Rafic Hariri International Airport")
.[\[143\]](#cite_note-147)
 [Air France](/wiki/Air_France "Air France")
 and [Lufthansa](/wiki/Lufthansa "Lufthansa")
 suspended flights to Beirut (along with [Tel Aviv](/wiki/Tel_Aviv "Tel Aviv")
 and [Tehran](/wiki/Tehran "Tehran")
), citing the security situation caused by the attacks.[\[27\]](#cite_note-CNN-2-29)
[\[144\]](#cite_note-148)

#### Hezbollah

[CNN](/wiki/CNN "CNN")
 suggested that the operation was likely intended to instill paranoia among Hezbollah members, undermine their recruitment efforts, and weaken confidence in Hezbollah's leadership and its ability to protect its operations and personnel.[\[145\]](#cite_note-CNN-149)
 [John Miller](/wiki/John_Miller_(police_official) "John Miller (police official)")
, CNN's Chief Law Enforcement and Intelligence Analyst, stated the message for Hezbollah was that "We can reach you anywhere, anytime, at the day and moment of our choosing and we can do it at the press of a button."[\[145\]](#cite_note-CNN-149)

_[The Economist](/wiki/The_Economist "The Economist")
_ suggested that the pager-bombs, aimed at disrupting Hezbollah's command and communications structure, could be a precursor to an Israeli invasion. He argued that the loss or damage to a small number of civilians was not excessive in relation to the military advantage of removing many Hezbollah operatives from the battlefield and destroying the organization's trust in their communications.[\[177\]](#cite_note-bergin-181)
 Former Australian Minister for Defence Materiel [Mike Kelly](/wiki/Mike_Kelly_(Australian_politician) "Mike Kelly (Australian politician)")
, characterized the method as "as precise as it is possible to be in neutralising Hezbollah's key command and control matrix," noting that the devices were ordered by Hezbollah specifically for its most senior personnel to avoid tracking.[\[177\]](#cite_note-bergin-181)

Reactions
---------

### Lebanon

A senior Lebanese security source told _[Al-Hadath](/wiki/Al-Hadath "Al-Hadath")
_ that Israel had infiltrated the communication systems of individual devices, leading to their detonation.[\[94\]](#cite_note-The_Jerusalem_Post-2-97)
 The office of Prime Minister Mikati said the incident was a criminal "violation of Lebanese sovereignty" by Israel.[\[24\]](#cite_note-The_New_York_Times-3-26)
 The government contacted the [United Nations](/wiki/United_Nations "United Nations")
, asking them to hold Israel responsible for the attack.[\[27\]](#cite_note-CNN-2-29)
 Health Minister [Firas Abiad](/wiki/Firas_Abiad "Firas Abiad")
 praised the health system's response, noting the system was able to "get care to those who needed it, especially for those with serious injuries".[\[178\]](#cite_note-182)

Lebanese journalist Mohammad Barakat, known for his anti-Hezbollah views, called the pager attacks a "Lebanese [9/11](/wiki/September_11_attacks "September 11 attacks")
".[\[179\]](#cite_note-183)
 The Lebanese newspaper _[Al-Akhbar](/wiki/Al_Akhbar_(Lebanon) "Al Akhbar (Lebanon)")
_ reported that "the enemy succeeded in directing its harshest blows to the body of the Islamic Resistance since the beginning of the conflict with the enemy, in an exceptional security operation in terms of the ability to reach targets and means".[\[180\]](#cite_note-184)

On 6 November 2024, Lebanon filed a complaint against Israel in the [International Labour Organization](/wiki/International_Labour_Organization "International Labour Organization")
 (ILO) over the attacks, with labour minister [Mustafa Bairam](/w/index.php?title=Mustafa_Bairam&action=edit&redlink=1 "Mustafa Bairam (page does not exist)")
 \[[ar](https://ar.wikipedia.org/wiki/%D9%85%D8%B5%D8%B7%D9%81%D9%89_%D8%A8%D9%8A%D8%B1%D9%85 "ar:مصطفى بيرم")\
; [de](https://de.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mustafa_Bayram "de:Mustafa Bayram")\
\] citing the threats posed by the explosions to workplace safety as his reason to submit the complaint to the ILO.[\[181\]](#cite_note-185)

#### Hezbollah

Hezbollah described Israel's attacks as "criminal aggression" and pledged a "just retribution".[\[97\]](#cite_note-BBC-2-100)
 Those close to the group described a state of shock following the explosions.[\[64\]](#cite_note-The_Economist-67)
 Lebanese analyst Qassim Qassir said the attacks mostly struck civilian workers within Hezbollah, and not fighters.[\[131\]](#cite_note-:13-135)

Eight days before [his assassination on 27 September 2024](/wiki/2024_Hezbollah_headquarters_strike "2024 Hezbollah headquarters strike")
, Hezbollah's Secretary-General Nasrallah called the attack a "severe blow", describing it as "unprecedented" for Hezbollah, Lebanon and possibly the region.[\[32\]](#cite_note-:5-34)
 He added that Israel had crossed all "red lines".[\[182\]](#cite_note-186)
 Nasrallah challenged the IDF to invade Lebanon, claiming Hezbollah was ready, and said that Israelis displaced in the north would only be allowed to return if Israel ceased the invasion of Gaza.[\[183\]](#cite_note-187)

On the morning of 22 September, Hezbollah retaliated by firing dozens of rockets at northern Israel.[\[184\]](#cite_note-:7-188)
 Some of the rockets were intercepted over [Haifa](/wiki/Haifa "Haifa")
 and [Nazareth](/wiki/Nazareth "Nazareth")
.[\[184\]](#cite_note-:7-188)
 In [Kiryat Bialik](/wiki/Kiryat_Bialik "Kiryat Bialik")
, two houses were struck. [Archived](https://web.archive.org/web/20240919213419/https://apnews.com/article/lebanon-israel-hezbollah-pager-explosion-e9493409a0648b846fdcadffdb02d71e)
     from the original on 19 September 2024. [Archived](https://web.archive.org/web/20240919060924/https://edition.cnn.com/2024/09/17/middleeast/lebanon-hezbollah-pagers-explosions-intl/index.html)
     from the original on 19 September 2024. [Archived](https://web.archive.org/web/20240918150311/https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2024/9/18/multiple-explosions-heard-in-lebanon-a-day-after-hezbollah-pager-blasts)
     from the original on 18 September 2024. [Archived](https://web.archive.org/web/20240920090211/https://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2024/sep/18/middle-east-crisis-live-hezbollah-pager-explosion-lebanon-irael-iran-latest-updates)
     from the original on 20 September 2024."

# Your Summary



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The search result from Wikipedia discusses the 2024 Lebanon electronic device attacks, which occurred in September 2024. The attacks involved explosions of pagers and walkie-talkies, resulting in numerous casualties. The attacks were attributed to Israel and targeted Hezbollah members. The first wave of explosions on September 17, 2024, targeted pagers, killing at least 12 people and injuring over 2,750. The second wave on September 18, 2024, targeted walkie-talkies, killing at least 30 people and injuring over 750. <image:10226> is a picture of the remnants of a Hezbollah pager that exploded on September 17, 2024. The attacks were described as a major blow to Hezbollah, and Hezbollah retaliated by firing rockets at northern Israel.

# Instructions
In order to find evidence that helps your fact-check, you just ran a web search which yielded a Search Result. **Your task right now is to summarize the Search Result.** What to include:

* relevant images (refer to images by inserting their reference <image:k>)
* if available: the release date as well as the author or the publisher (e.g. the media company) of the search result.

Do NOT include:
* advertisements
* any other information not related to the Record or the Claim

* Do not add any additional information besides the information in the Search Result.
* If the Search Result doesn't contain any relevant information for the fact-checking work, simply print one word in capital letters: "NONE".
* Keep your writing style like in the Examples 1, 2 and 3 provided to you.
* Try to filter out relevant information even if the search result is in a different language.

[![People stand outside a hospital emergency room](/sites/default/files/styles/embed_xxl/public/media_2024/09/202409mena_lebanon_beirut_pagers_hospital.jpg?itok=ogwjO0Rc)\
\
Click to expand Image](/modal/107649)

Families of people who were injured by their exploded handheld pagers wait at the emergency entrance of the American University hospital in Beirut, Lebanon, September 18, 2024.  © 2024 AP Photo/Hussein Malla

(Beirut) – Thousands of pagers simultaneously exploded across [Lebanon](https://www.hrw.org/middle-east/n-africa/lebanon)
 and parts of Syria on September 17, 2024, resulting in at least [12 deaths](https://today.lorientlejour.com/article/1427494/after-pager-explosions-hezbollah-announces-death-of-10-fighters-vows-to-continue-operations-day-348-of-the-gaza-war.html)
, including at least two children and two health workers, and at least [2,800 injuries](https://today.lorientlejour.com/article/1427437/thousands-across-lebanon-injured-in-hezbollah-pager-explosions-what-we-know-so-far.html)
, according to Lebanon’s Ministry of Health.

Photographs and videos filmed by victims and witnesses to the incident and reviewed by Human Rights Watch showed pagers exploding in various locales, such as grocery stores. and limbs, and other injuries consistent with the detonation of high explosives. 

Hezbollah, in a [statement](https://mediarelations-lb.org/post.php?id=19032)
, said that the pagers belonged “to employees of various Hezbollah units and institutions” and blamed the Israeli government. [US](https://www.nytimes.com/2024/09/17/world/middleeast/israel-hezbollah-pagers-explosives.html)
 and [former Israeli officials](https://www.axios.com/2024/09/18/hezbollah-pager-explosions-israel-suspicions)
 speaking to the media said that Israel was responsible for the attack. A prompt and impartial investigation into the attacks should be urgently conducted.”

Your tax deductible gift can help stop human rights violations and save lives around the world.

.

##### **The following quote can be attributed to Lama Fakih, Middle East and North Africa Director at Human Rights Watch:**

> “Customary international humanitarian law prohibits the use of booby traps – objects that civilians are likely to be attracted to or are associated with normal civilian daily use – precisely to avoid putting civilians at grave risk and produce the devastating scenes that continue to unfold across Lebanon today. # Your Summary



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
Human Rights Watch published an article on September 18, 2024, about exploding pagers in Lebanon on September 17, 2024, which resulted in at least 12 deaths and 2,800 injuries. <image:10226> is not present in the search result.

_________________________



SummarizeSummariesPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
You just retrieved web sources, each one summarized under "Web Sources". **Your task right now is to summarize the web source summaries.**

Always adhere to the following rules:
* Write only one to two paragraphs.
* Include all URLs from the listed sources. Format them as Markdown hyperlinks.
* Do not add any additional information besides the information in the summaries.
* Include references (<image:k>) to all relevant images.

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "<image:10226> This image shows an Iphone that exploded during the pager attacks on Hezbollah devices in Lebanon in September 2024, blowing up random people."

## Actions
```
reverse_search(<image:10226>)
web_search("Hezbollah Lebanon September 2024 phone explosion")
```

## Web Sources
**Web Search Result**

From [Source](https://lieber.westpoint.edu/well-it-depends-explosive-pagers-attack-revisited/): 
Content: The search result from Lieber Institute of Law & Warfare discusses the explosive pager attacks on Hezbollah operatives in Lebanon and Syria on September 17, 2024. The article mentions that Israel is strongly suggested to be responsible for the explosions. The explosions resulted in injuries and deaths, with twelve people reportedly killed. The article was published on October 11, 2024.


From [Source](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2024_Lebanon_electronic_device_attacks): 
Content: The search result from Wikipedia discusses the 2024 Lebanon electronic device attacks, which occurred in September 2024. The attacks involved explosions of pagers and walkie-talkies, resulting in numerous casualties. The attacks were attributed to Israel and targeted Hezbollah members. The first wave of explosions on September 17, 2024, targeted pagers, killing at least 12 people and injuring over 2,750. The second wave on September 18, 2024, targeted walkie-talkies, killing at least 30 people and injuring over 750. <image:10226> is a picture of the remnants of a Hezbollah pager that exploded on September 17, 2024. The attacks were described as a major blow to Hezbollah, and Hezbollah retaliated by firing rockets at northern Israel.


From [Source](https://www.hrw.org/news/2024/09/18/lebanon-exploding-pagers-harmed-hezbollah-civilians): 
Content: Human Rights Watch published an article on September 18, 2024, about exploding pagers in Lebanon on September 17, 2024, which resulted in at least 12 deaths and 2,800 injuries. <image:10226> is not present in the search result.


## Your Summary



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The web sources discuss the 2024 Lebanon electronic device attacks, which occurred in September 2024. The attacks involved explosions of pagers and walkie-talkies, resulting in numerous casualties. The attacks were attributed to Israel and targeted Hezbollah members. The first wave of explosions on September 17, 2024, targeted pagers, killing at least 12 people and injuring over 2,750. The second wave on September 18, 2024, targeted walkie-talkies, killing at least 30 people and injuring over 750.

One source mentions that <image:10226>
_________________________



DevelopPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
You just retrieved new Evidence. Now, **analyze the Claim's veracity using the evidence**. Always adhere to the following rules:
* Focus on developing new insights. Do not repeat larger parts from the Record. Do not restate the Claim.
* Write down your thoughts step-by-step. Whenever necessary, you may elaborate in more detail.
* Depending on the topic's complexity, invest one to three paragraphs. The fewer, the better.
* If you find that there is insufficient information to verify the Claim, explicitly state what information is missing.
* If you cite web sources, always refer to them by including their URL as a Markdown hyperlink.
* **Use information only from the recorded evidence**: Avoid inserting information that is not implied by the evidence. You may use commonsense knowledge, though.

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "<image:10226> This image shows an Iphone that exploded during the pager attacks on Hezbollah devices in Lebanon in September 2024, blowing up random people."

## Actions
```
reverse_search(<image:10226>)
web_search("Hezbollah Lebanon September 2024 phone explosion")
```

## Evidence
### Evidence from `reverse_search`
The image <image:10226>

### Evidence from `web_search`
The web sources discuss the 2024 Lebanon electronic device attacks, which occurred in September 2024. The attacks involved explosions of pagers and walkie-talkies, resulting in numerous casualties. The attacks were attributed to Israel and targeted Hezbollah members. The first wave of explosions on September 17, 2024, targeted pagers, killing at least 12 people and injuring over 2,750. The second wave on September 18, 2024, targeted walkie-talkies, killing at least 30 people and injuring over 750.

One source mentions that <image:10226>

# Your Analysis



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The evidence indicates that the attacks in Lebanon in September 2024 involved explosions of pagers and walkie-talkies, not iPhones. The image shows an iPhone, but there is no evidence to support the claim that it exploded during the attacks. The attacks targeted Hezbollah members, and the claim states that random people were blown up.

The claim is not supported by the evidence.

_________________________



JudgePrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
**Determine the Claim's veracity** by following these steps:
1. Briefly summarize the key insights from the fact-check (see Record) in at most one paragraph.
2. Write one paragraph about which one of the Decision Options applies best. Include the most appropriate decision option at the end and enclose it in backticks like `this`.




## Decision Options
* `true`: The claim is factually accurate when it is confirmed by evidence from multiple and reliable sources.
* `not enough information`: The fact-check does not contain sufficient information to come to an conclusion. For example,there is substantial lack of evidence or the evidence is inconclusive, conflicting or self-contradictory. In the case of a lack of evidence, state which information exactly is missing. In particular, if no RESULTS or sources are available, pick this decision.
* `false`: The claim is not factually accurate. This is the case if one of the following three conditions is met:(1) The claim is demonstrably false when it is disproven by evidence from multiple and reliable sources,(2) The claim or image is taken out of context, i.e. the origin, content and/or meaning of a statement or an image is misrepresented. For example, an old claim or an old image is mispresented in a new context in a misleading way,(3) There is not enough evidence to verify the claim or the evidence is conflicting or self-contradictory.

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "<image:10226> This image shows an Iphone that exploded during the pager attacks on Hezbollah devices in Lebanon in September 2024, blowing up random people."

## Actions
```
reverse_search(<image:10226>)
web_search("Hezbollah Lebanon September 2024 phone explosion")
```

## Evidence
### Evidence from `reverse_search`
The image <image:10226>

### Evidence from `web_search`
The web sources discuss the 2024 Lebanon electronic device attacks, which occurred in September 2024. The attacks involved explosions of pagers and walkie-talkies, resulting in numerous casualties. The attacks were attributed to Israel and targeted Hezbollah members. The first wave of explosions on September 17, 2024, targeted pagers, killing at least 12 people and injuring over 2,750. The second wave on September 18, 2024, targeted walkie-talkies, killing at least 30 people and injuring over 750.

One source mentions that <image:10226>

## Elaboration
The evidence indicates that the attacks in Lebanon in September 2024 involved explosions of pagers and walkie-talkies, not iPhones. The image shows an iPhone, but there is no evidence to support the claim that it exploded during the attacks. The attacks targeted Hezbollah members, and the claim states that random people were blown up.

The claim is not supported by the evidence.


# Your Judgement



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The provided evidence indicates that the attacks in Lebanon in September 2024 involved explosions of pagers and walkie-talkies, not iPhones. The image shows an iPhone, but there is no evidence to support the claim that it exploded during the attacks. The attacks targeted Hezbollah members, and the claim states that random people were blown up.

`false`
_________________________



SummarizeDocPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
You are provided with the record of a fact-check. It contains the Claim to be verified and a documentation of all the fact-checking work along the gathered evidence. Your task is to **summarize the fact-check**. That is, you provide a concise, one-paragraph justification for the final VERDICT based on the knowledge from the Record. Note:
* Be truthful, brief, do not add any additional information besides the information given in the Record. 
* Link key sources in your summary. Use Markdown notation for that. You may link them in-line.
* Don't state the Claim again. Rather focus on the key insights of the fact-check.
* Simply print just the summary.

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "<image:10226> This image shows an Iphone that exploded during the pager attacks on Hezbollah devices in Lebanon in September 2024, blowing up random people."

## Actions
```
reverse_search(<image:10226>)
web_search("Hezbollah Lebanon September 2024 phone explosion")
```

## Evidence
### Evidence from `reverse_search`
The image <image:10226>

### Evidence from `web_search`
The web sources discuss the 2024 Lebanon electronic device attacks, which occurred in September 2024. The attacks involved explosions of pagers and walkie-talkies, resulting in numerous casualties. The attacks were attributed to Israel and targeted Hezbollah members. The first wave of explosions on September 17, 2024, targeted pagers, killing at least 12 people and injuring over 2,750. The second wave on September 18, 2024, targeted walkie-talkies, killing at least 30 people and injuring over 750.

One source mentions that <image:10226>

## Elaboration
The evidence indicates that the attacks in Lebanon in September 2024 involved explosions of pagers and walkie-talkies, not iPhones. The image shows an iPhone, but there is no evidence to support the claim that it exploded during the attacks. The attacks targeted Hezbollah members, and the claim states that random people were blown up.

The claim is not supported by the evidence.


## Final Judgement
The provided evidence indicates that the attacks in Lebanon in September 2024 involved explosions of pagers and walkie-talkies, not iPhones. The image shows an iPhone, but there is no evidence to support the claim that it exploded during the attacks. The attacks targeted Hezbollah members, and the claim states that random people were blown up.

`false`

## Summary



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The claim is false. While there were attacks in Lebanon in September 2024, they involved explosions of pagers and walkie-talkies, not iPhones. The image depicts an iPhone, but there is no evidence to support the claim that it exploded during the attacks.

_________________________



PlanPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
The available knowledge is insufficient to assess the Claim. Therefore, **propose a set of actions** to retrieve new and helpful evidence. Adhere to the following rules:
* The actions available are listed under Valid Actions, including a short description for each action. No other actions are possible at this moment. 
* For each action, use the formatting as specified in Valid Actions.
* Include all actions in a single Markdown code block at the end of your answer.
* Propose as few actions as possible, but as much as needed. Do not propose similar or previously used actions.



## Valid Actions
* `reverse_search`
   * Description: Performs a reverse image search to find similar images on the web.
   * How to use: Provide an image and the model will perform a reverse search to find similar images.
   * Format: reverse_search(<image:k>), where `k` is the image's ID

* `geolocate`
   * Description: Performs geolocation to determine the country where an image was taken.
   * How to use: Provide an image and the model will determine the most likely countries where it was taken.
   * Format: geolocate(<image:k>), where `k` is the image's ID

* `web_search`
   * Description: Run an open web search on Google or DuckDuckGO to retrieve any related webpage.
   * How to use: Do not use this with a previously used or similar query from previous web searches. If a previous web search did not yield any results, use a very different query.
   * Format: web_search("your web search query goes here")

# Example: reverse_search()

## Claim
Text: "<image:k> shows a rare event of a solar eclipse with a double ring."

...

## Actions
```
reverse_search(<image:k>)
```

# Example: geolocate()

## Claim
Text: "<image:k> shows a nuclear weapons facility in Usbekistan."

...

## Actions
```
geolocate(<image:k>)
```

# Example: web_search()

## Claim
Text: "New Zealand’s new Food Bill bans gardening"
Claim date: October 29, 2020

...

## Actions
```
web_search("New Zealand Food Bill 2020")
web_search("New Zealand Food Bill gardening ban")
```

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "<image:10233> This image shows two children in Gaza in April 2025 found dead under the rubble of their home two months after an Israeli airstrike destroyed it."

# Your Actions



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
```
reverse_search(<image:10233>)
web_search("children found under rubble Gaza")
```
_________________________



SummarizeResultPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
In order to find evidence that helps your fact-check, you just ran a web search which yielded a Search Result. **Your task right now is to summarize the Search Result.** What to include:
* information that might be useful for the fact-check (see Record)
* relevant images (refer to images by inserting their reference <image:k>)
* if available: the release date as well as the author or the publisher (e.g. the media company) of the search result.

Do NOT include:
* advertisements
* any other information not related to the Record or the Claim

Additional rules:
* Do not add any additional information besides the information in the Search Result.
* If the Search Result doesn't contain any relevant information for the fact-checking work, simply print one word in capital letters: "NONE".
* Keep your writing style like in the Examples 1, 2 and 3 provided to you.
* Try to filter out relevant information even if the search result is in a different language.

# Example 1
The search result from America Today provides several photographs of the Notre-Dame Cathedral fire on April 15, 2019. <image:i>, <image:j>, <image:k>. None of the images show the Eiffel Tower in the background. 

# Example 2
NONE

# Example 3
The Guardian discusses a report blaming the Syrian government for a toxic gas attack and condemning their use of chemical weapons. The Guardian mentions the Chemical Weapons Convention and the responsibilities of Syria under the convention. According to The Guardian, The White House condemned the Assad regime for defying the norm against chemical weapons use.

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "<image:10233> This image shows two children in Gaza in April 2025 found dead under the rubble of their home two months after an Israeli airstrike destroyed it."

## Actions
```
reverse_search(<image:10233>)
web_search("children found under rubble Gaza")
```

 [Pinterest](https://pinterest.com/pin/create/button/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fkashif.ps%2Fen%2Findex.php%2F2025%2F04%2F14%2Fimage-of-two-mummified-children-in-a-bolivian-museum-goes-viral-as-from-gaza%2F&media=https%3A%2F%2Fkashif.ps%2Fen%2Fwp-content%2Fuploads%2F2025%2F04%2FScreenshot-2025-04-12-at-10.59.20%E2%80%AFpm.png&description=Image%20of%20two%20mummified%20children%20in%20a%20Bolivian%20museum%20goes%20viral%20as%20from%20Gaza "Pinterest")
 [Email](mailto:?subject=Image%20of%20two%20mummified%20children%20in%20a%20Bolivian%20museum%20goes%20viral%20as%20from%20Gaza&body=https%3A%2F%2Fkashif.ps%2Fen%2Findex.php%2F2025%2F04%2F14%2Fimage-of-two-mummified-children-in-a-bolivian-museum-goes-viral-as-from-gaza%2F "Email")

Social media accounts posted [a photo](https://www.instagram.com/p/DISBVcfsfgU/)
 of two young children appearing as skeletons, claiming that the image shows two children found two months later under the rubble of their home in the Gaza Strip. The caption for the photo reads, “Two children found two months later under the rubble of their home.” Share, don’t just remain silent. 

[! <image:11636>](https://www.instagram.com/p/DISBVcfsfgU/)

Source of the claim

Kashif verified the image via Google Images search and found it to be old and the claim misleading. The image depicts two Spanish mummified children inside a museum in Bolivia, not two children found under rubble in the Gaza Strip.

The photo was posted on Fliker by an account named [Tanya Knigh on 25/12/2006, and was explained as showing two mummified Spanish children from the 19th century at the Mint Museum in Potosi, Bolivia.](https://www.flickr.com/photos/smurfie77/333238377?fbclid=PAZXh0bgNhZW0CMTEAAaf-NowrYSPdQib6AwuqOgbujlriQwuln3oY-zG75oLRNBKRISpoXJq0vayn1A_aem_WdbZCYRlh2m7hO3aQi4zFQ)

He accompanied the photo [with the](https://www.flickr.com/photos/smurfie77/333238377?fbclid=PAZXh0bgNhZW0CMTEAAaf-NowrYSPdQib6AwuqOgbujlriQwuln3oY-zG75oLRNBKRISpoXJq0vayn1A_aem_WdbZCYRlh2m7hO3aQi4zFQ)
 following description: “What you find in museums is always surprising. At the Mint Museum in Potosi, Bolivia, I found two mummified Spanish children from the 19th century. Horrific stuff.

[! <image:11637>](https://www.flickr.com/photos/smurfie77/333238377?fbclid=PAZXh0bgNhZW0CMTEAAaf-NowrYSPdQib6AwuqOgbujlriQwuln3oY-zG75oLRNBKRISpoXJq0vayn1A_aem_WdbZCYRlh2m7hO3aQi4zFQ)

Photo posted by [Ask the Knight](https://www.flickr.com/photos/smurfie77/333238377?fbclid=PAZXh0bgNhZW0CMTEAAaf-NowrYSPdQib6AwuqOgbujlriQwuln3oY-zG75oLRNBKRISpoXJq0vayn1A_aem_WdbZCYRlh2m7hO3aQi4zFQ)
 = on Fliker on 25/12/2006

Aa the Israeli occupation’s aggression against the Gaza Strip continues [the Palestinian Ministry of Health in Gaza](https://www.facebook.com/MOHGaza1994/posts/pfbid02LSbFXAhwvccuYfo8Lew2EUQDL7ceufhfFmQFev46YU4nnUvcYFFh3qkkSekHU1fKl)
 documented 50,933 citizens killed and 116,045 wounded, including 15,000 children , and more than 34,000 other children wounded since 7/10/2023.

# Your Summary



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The image in the claim shows two mummified children from a Bolivian museum, not children found under the rubble in Gaza. The image was posted on Instagram with the caption "Two children found two months later under the rubble of their home." The article was published on April 14, 2025, by Nadeen. <image:10233>, <image:11636>, <image:11637>.

SummarizeResultPrompt - QUERY:

# Instructions
In order to find evidence that helps your fact-check, you just ran a web search which yielded a Search Result. **Your task right now is to summarize the Search Result.** What to include:
* information that might be useful for the fact-check (see Record)
* relevant images (refer to images by inserting their reference <image:k>)
* if available: the release date as well as the author or the publisher (e.g. the media company) of the search result.

Do NOT include:
* advertisements
* any other information not related to the Record or the Claim

Additional rules:
* Do not add any additional information besides the information in the Search Result.
* If the Search Result doesn't contain any relevant information for the fact-checking work, simply print one word in capital letters: "NONE".
* Keep your writing style like in the Examples 1, 2 and 3 provided to you.
* Try to filter out relevant information even if the search result is in a different language.

# Example 1
The search result from America Today provides several photographs of the Notre-Dame Cathedral fire on April 15, 2019. <image:i>, <image:j>, <image:k>. None of the images show the Eiffel Tower in the background.

The Guardian discusses a report blaming the Syrian government for a toxic gas attack and condemning their use of chemical weapons. The Guardian mentions the Chemical Weapons Convention and the responsibilities of Syria under the convention. According to The Guardian, The White House condemned the Assad regime for defying the norm against chemical weapons use.

# Record
## Claim
Claim: "<image:10233> This image shows two children in Gaza in April 2025 found dead under the rubble of their home two months after an Israeli airstrike destroyed it."

## Actions
```
reverse_search(<image:10233>)
web_search("children found under rubble Gaza")
```

# Search Result
From [Source](https://reliefweb.int/report/occupied-palestinian-territory/gazas-missing-children-over-20000-children-estimated-be-lost-disappeared-detained-buried-under-rubble-or-mass-graves-0): 
Content: "[Skip to main content](#main-content)

Ask about this document
-----------------------

[Go to chat page](/ai/chat/popup?url=https%3A//reliefweb.int/report/occupied-palestinian-territory/gazas-missing-children-over-20000-children-estimated-be-lost-disappeared-detained-buried-under-rubble-or-mass-graves-0&limit=1)

**GAZA, 25 June 2024 –** Up to 21,000 \[1\] children are estimated to be missing in the chaos of the war in Gaza, many trapped beneath rubble, detained, buried in unmarked graves, or lost from their families, said Save the Children. The agency’s child protection teams are reporting that the latest displacements caused by the offensive in Rafah have separated more children and further increased the strain on families and communities caring for them.

It is nearly impossible to collect and verify information under the current conditions in Gaza, but at least 17,000 children are believed to [be unaccompanied and separated](https://www.unicef.org/press-releases/stories-loss-and-grief-least-17000-children-are-estimated-be-unaccompanied-or)
 and approximately 4,000 children are likely missing under the rubble \[2\], with an unknown number also in [mass graves](https://www.ohchr.org/en/press-releases/2024/05/onslaught-violence-against-women-and-children-gaza-unacceptable-un-experts#:~:text=Over%20390%20bodies%20have%20been,alive%2C%E2%80%9D%20the%20experts%20said)
. Save the Children added these estimates to equal approximately 21,000 children missing in Gaza, or over 20,000.

\[2\] The UN estimates that [10,000 people](https://news.un.org/en/story/2024/05/1149256)
 are believed buried under the rubble in Gaza, and also estimates that [40% of casualties](https://www.unocha.org/news/gaza-children-under-attack)
 in Gaza are children. Save the Children estimates this would amount to approximately 4,000 children buried under the rubble in Gaza.

\[3\] According to latest figures from the Ministry of Health in Gaza, more than 14,100 children have been killed in Gaza since 7 October, of which 7,779 have been identified. Others have been forcibly disappeared, including an unknown number [detained and forcibly transferred](https://www.ohchr.org/en/press-releases/2024/02/israelopt-un-experts-appalled-reported-human-rights-violations-against)
 out of Gaza, their whereabouts unknown to their families amidst [reports of ill-treatment and torture.](https://www.unrwa.org/sites/default/files/content/resources/summary_on_detention_and_alleged_ill-treatmentupdated.pdf)

Meanwhile, the aid agency’s child protection teams warn of the urgent action needed to protect separated and unaccompanied children – action that is severely undermined by the deteriorating security situation.

**A Save the Children Child Protection Specialist in Gaza said:**

_"Every day we find more unaccompanied children and every day it is harder to support them. Children are also among those recently found in mass graves, [according to UN experts](https://www.ohchr.org/en/press-releases/2024/05/onslaught-violence-against-women-and-children-gaza-unacceptable-un-experts#:~:text=Over%20390%20bodies%20have%20been,alive%2C%E2%80%9D%20the%20experts%20said.)
, with many showing signs of torture and summary executions, as well as potential [instances of people buried alive](https://www.ohchr.org/en/press-releases/2024/05/onslaught-violence-against-women-and-children-gaza-unacceptable-un-experts#:~:text=Over%20390%20bodies%20have%20been,alive%2C%E2%80%9D%20the%20experts%20said)
.

At least 33 Israeli children have been killed since October, while it is unclear if any children are among those still being held hostage in Gaza. This includes [17,000 unaccompanied and separated children](https://www.unicef.org/press-releases/stories-loss-and-grief-least-17000-children-are-estimated-be-unaccompanied-or)
, and 4,000 children buried under the rubble \[see 2 below\]. We work through partners to identify separated and unaccompanied children and trace their families, but there are no safe facilities for them – there is no safe place in Gaza. Save the Children warned that confirming identification of a body by the next of kin is almost impossible when whole families have been wiped out and entry restrictions mean the equipment and experts needed cannot get in.

According to Gaza’s Ministry of Health, [more than 14,000 children](https://www.unicef.org/emergencies/children-gaza-need-lifesaving-support#:~:text=More%20than%2014%2C000%20children%20have,which%20will%20last%20a%20lifetime.)
 have been killed since 7 October, roughly half of whom have not yet been fully identified, partially due to their bodies being harmed beyond recognition \[3\]. No child should be detained or held hostage._

_“Children who are missing but living are vulnerable, face grave protection risks and must be found."

# Your Summary



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The search result from Reliefweb, published on June 25, 2024, discusses the situation of children in Gaza. It estimates that approximately 4,000 children are likely missing under the rubble. The article also mentions that over 14,000 children have been killed in Gaza since October.

_________________________

# Instructions
In order to find evidence that helps your fact-check, you just ran a web search which yielded a Search Result. **Your task right now is to summarize the Search Result.** What to include:

* relevant images (refer to images by inserting their reference <image:k>)

# Search Result
From [Source](https://www.savethechildren.net/gaza-missing-children): 
Content: "Photo: Bisan Owda / Save the Children.

At the same time, the unrelenting intensity of the war in Gaza, movement and access restrictions, and communication blackouts have made it difficult to keep track of and locate children who have been separated and detained. 

This means that the true number of missing children in Gaza is even higher.

* * *

You can protect the lives of children living in crisis around the world.

[Donate now](https://donate.savethechildren.org/en/donate/children-crisis-donate-child-emergency-fund)

**Where are Gaza's missing children?**
--------------------------------------

                    ![](<Base64-Image-Removed>)

   

 ![](<Base64-Image-Removed>)

   

 ![](<Base64-Image-Removed>)

   

 ![](<Base64-Image-Removed>)

   

 ![](<Base64-Image-Removed>)

   

**1\.** **Under the rubble**

Israeli forces have dropped [75,000 tonnes](https://www.aljazeera.com/gallery/2024/4/23/photos-200-days-of-israels-war-on-gaza)
 of explosives – the equivalent of [6 nuclear bombs](https://euromedmonitor.org/en/article/5908/Israel-hits-Gaza-Strip-with-the-equivalent-of-two-nuclear-bombs#:~:text=Geneva%20%2D%20Israel%20has%20dropped%20more,a%20press%20release%20issued%20today)
 – on Gaza, turning homes, schools, hospitals and places of worship into rubble. [Skip to main content](#main-content)

    

[DONATE](https://www.savethechildren.org.uk/donate)

**THE MISSING CHILDREN OF GAZA**
================================

 ![](<Base64-Image-Removed>)

   

### **Countless children are missing in Gaza.**

Thousands are presumed dead beneath the rubble. Their condition is unknown, and their loved ones are living with the uncertainty of not knowing if their children are alive. 

![](<Base64-Image-Removed>)

![](<Base64-Image-Removed>)

 ![People search the rubble in Gaza. Bisan Owda / Save the Children](<Base64-Image-Removed>)

People search the rubble in Gaza. Photo: Bisan Owda / Save the Children.

People search the rubble in Gaza. That they’ll see their face again one day.

**But that day will not come until a lasting ceasefire.** Only then can we see the truth and begin the search for justice and peace. 

* * *

#### **Together we can stop the war on children.**

[Join us and call for a ceasefire now](https://donate.savethechildren.org/en/takeaction/stop-war-children)

Image captions
--------------

![](<Base64-Image-Removed>)

![](<Base64-Image-Removed>)

   

![](<Base64-Image-Removed>)

![](<Base64-Image-Removed>)

   

**How many children are missing?**
----------------------------------

### **We can’t be sure.**

At least **10,000 people are reported missing** under the rubble, presumed dead. Children are reported to make up 43% of total casualties in this devastating war.

#### So, it’s reasonable to estimate that at least **5,160 children are dead** under the rubble. This number is likely much higher now, with our team in Gaza finding more unaccompanied children every day. 

Furthermore, the bodies of children have been among those recently found in [mass graves](https://www.ohchr.org/en/press-releases/2024/05/onslaught-violence-against-women-and-children-gaza-unacceptable-un-experts#:~:text=Over%20390%20bodies%20have%20been,alive%2C%E2%80%9D%20the%20experts%20said.)
 with many showing signs of torture.

The UN has also raised the alarm about the mass detention of possibly thousands of people, including children, reporting cases of ill-treatment in detention by Israeli forces.

The ongoing violence in Gaza has disrupted communications, and the attacks on hospitals have made it extremely difficult for medical staff to report death tolls and identify those killed. Photo: Bisan Owda / Save the Children.

A child's doll amongst the rubble in Gaza. **Children aren’t likely to survive being crushed by entire apartment buildings.** 

### **2.** **Maimed beyond recognition**

Children – who are [seven times more likely](https://www.savethechildren.org.uk/news/media-centre/press-releases/worlds-first-research-centre-child-blast-injuries)
 to die from blast injuries than adults due to their still developing and vulnerable bodies – have suffered such horrific injuries from bombs and collapsed buildings that their bodies are beyond recognition.

Added to that, forensic and human rights experts can’t enter Gaza and even if they could, wouldn’t have the safety or the resources they need to identify children’s remains. 

### **3.** **Mass graves**  

Palestinian authorities and [UN experts](https://www.ohchr.org/en/press-releases/2024/05/onslaught-violence-against-women-and-children-gaza-unacceptable-un-experts#:~:text=Over%20390%20bodies%20have%20been,alive%2C%E2%80%9D%20the%20experts%20said.))
 have found mass graves in and around hospitals throughout Gaza, with hundreds of bodies, including children.  

The spokesperson for the UN High Commissioner for Human Rights [described](https://news.un.org/en/story/2024/04/1148876)
 bodies _“buried deep in the ground and covered with waste_”, and that some were bound and stripped of their clothes. 

### **4\.** **Detained, "disappeared" or abducted**

Up to 3,000 people have been [detained in Gaza](https://www.unrwa.org/sites/default/files/content/resources/summary_on_detention_and_alleged_ill-treatmentupdated.pdf)
 including an unknown number of children."

# Your Summary



===== > RESPONSE:  < =====
The Save the Children website discusses the missing children of Gaza. It states that at least 10,000 people are reported missing under the rubble, and it is estimated that at least 5,160 children are dead under the rubble. The website also mentions mass graves and the detention of children. <image:10233> is not mentioned.

# Instructions
In order to find evidence that helps your fact-check, you just ran a web search which yielded a Search Result. **Your task right now is to summarize the Search Result.** What to include:
* information that might be useful for the fact-check (see Record)
* relevant images (refer to images by inserting their reference <image:k>)
* if available: the release date as well as the author or the publisher (e.g. the media company) of the search result.

Do NOT include:
* advertisements
* any other information not related to the Record or the Claim

Additional rules:
* Do not add any additional information besides the information in the Search Result.
* If the Search Result doesn't contain any relevant information for the fact-checking work, simply print one word in capital letters: "NONE".
* Keep your writing style like in the Examples 1, 2 and 3 provided to you.
* Try to filter out relevant information even if the search result is in a different language.
